title: Phillip Schofield rushes to aid of crying This Morning guests as they're forced to watch grandma be attacked in care home
text:
TV Phillip Schofield rushes to aid of crying This Morning guests as they're forced to watch grandma be attacked in care home The great grandmother's relatives caught nurse by hiding a spy camera in the television after finding bruises on her body Share   Phillip Schofield rushes to aid of crying guests Share this video Get celebs   
Back in January 2016, a cruel Bupa carer was caught on a spy cam manhandling an elderly patient before slamming her head against a chair. 
Poor 77-year-old Betty Boylan who has dementia was only vindicated when her family secretly set up the CCTV after finding bruises on her body. 
Her relatives hid the device inside a television because of the marks they found on the retired nurse when visiting her at the £1,000 a month care home. 
And, on today's This Morning , Betty's daughter and granddaughter burst into tears as they were forced to re-watch the disturbing footage in which twisted Bina Begum is seen lifting their relative by her hair and throwing her back into her seat. Bina Begum viciously grabs the great grandmother's head (Photo: SWNS.com) The cruel nurse then slams Betty back into the seat with force (Photo: SWNS.com) Betty was man-handled in the care home (Photo: ITV) Video Loading   Horrific footage shows Bupa carer manhandling elderly dementia patient Share this video Phillip rushed to help (Photo: ITV) He handed them tissues (Photo: ITV) Video Loading   Horrific footage shows Bupa carer manhandling elderly dementia patient Share this video Watch Next 
Phillip Schofield quickly rushed to get the guests some tissues, as both turned away from the screens. 
Betty's granddaughter added: "She's such a kind person, and wouldn't harm anyone. 
"The most she’d ever do to hurt you is kiss you to death." 
49-year-old Bina, from Birmingham, was arrested immediately and admitted ill treating and neglecting Betty. Betty was abused in the care home (Photo: ITV) Her relatives were so annoyed (Photo: ITV) They're devastated (Photo: ITV) 
Bupa have confirmed both carers were sacked after footage of them mistreating Betty Boylan came to light. 
But her relatives don't believe her sentence of a £270 fine was good enough. 
It was not the only time the pensioner suffered a vicious attack by the hands of carers at the Bupa-run Perry Locks Care Home in Birmingham. 
In other footage which is under investigation, another carer appears to be spraying deodorant in Betty's face. 
She then jokes it is "better than poo" when a colleague points out it went in the gran's mouth. 
Betty's family immediately reported the disturbing recording to police. 
Begum, who worked as an auxiliary nurse, avoided jail when magistrates handed her a 12-month community order with 40 hours of unpaid work and fined her £270. 
She was caught on September 15 last year. 
Betty, who has four grown-up children and is a grandmother of 10, is heard screaming in pain as the carer roughly pulls her forward as she tries to change her. 
Prosecutor Noreen Ashraf told the court Betty was "left slumped in her chair with significant leaning to her side" after the incident. She said: "The complainant does want to move her arm. The defendant forces her arm and pushes her back into the chair. 
"The complainant cries out. She slams her head back into the chair with significant force to cause the chair to rock." 
Begum said she accepted her actions were "reckless rather than intentional or deliberate" in a letter read out in court. 
Nazia Jan, defending, said Begum was "very, very remorseful". The spy cam found two occasions in which Betty appears to have been mistreated (Photo: SWNS.com) 
She added: "It's cost her her chosen career. 
"This act was completely out of character, blemished her good character and caused her unquantifiable distress." 
The secret camera also captured footage of another carer spraying deodorant over Betty, who tells her to "stop it" in the same week. 
In the footage, the woman can be heard laughing and saying "better than poo" when a colleague, who is also in the room, says "it's really gone in my mouth". 
West Midlands Police said a 43-year-old woman had been voluntarily interviewed "in connection with an assault on a 77-year-old woman in a care home". 
A spokesperson for the force said inquiries were ongoing relating to the deodorant incident. 
Speaking after Begum was sentenced, Betty's relatives hit out at the sentence and said she should have been jailed. Son-in-law Nigel Jarvis, 56,told how he installed the £200 secret camera in a hollowed out television in September last year after finding bruises on Betty in April. 
The dad-of-two said: "We brought up the bruises and managers dismissed us and gave no explanation. 
"So I bought the camera and hid it in a gutted TV. Within four days we had the footage of Begum slamming her head into the chair. 
"I felt sick as a dog when I saw that. We went straight down there and called the police. 
"The sentence was a disgrace. She should have gone to prison. That would have send a message to other carers who treat people like this. 
"I am disgusted by what she did. But I also feel sorry for her because she has to live with it for the rest of her life." 
Granddad-of-one Nigel said the family were also horrified when they saw footage of the carer spraying deodorant in Betty's face. 
He added: "That happened in the same week. Video Loading
